title: 103_s193
content: The "Flat Tax Act of 1993" is also known as the Flat Tax Act. It repeals the taxation of corporations. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 repeals various taxes related to corporations, including corporate income tax, alternative minimum tax for corporations, unrelated business income tax, accumulated earnings tax, personal holding company tax, and taxes on life insurance companies, other insurance companies, regulated investment companies, and real estate investment trusts. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 repeals various taxes related to corporations, including corporate income tax, alternative minimum tax for corporations, unrelated business income tax, accumulated earnings tax, personal holding company tax, and taxes on life insurance companies, other insurance companies, regulated investment companies, and real estate investment trusts. Additionally, it includes tax provisions related to real estate investment trusts and income of foreign corporations connected with United States business. SEC. 3. 10 PERCENT INCOME TAX RATE FOR INDIVIDUALS. Section 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to impose a 10 percent income tax rate for individuals. A 10 percent income tax rate is imposed on individuals based on the excess of earned income over the exemption amount, which is $10,000 adjusted for the cost of living. The term 'earned income' is defined as income exceeding the exemption amount, subject to a 10 percent tax rate. The Consumer Price Index is used to calculate adjustments, rounded to the nearest multiple of $10. The term 'earned income' includes wages, self-employment earnings, and certain dividends. It excludes pensions, annuities, and discretionary tips. The cost of fringe benefits included as earned income is the employer's expense. SEC. 4. Repeal of special deductions, credits, and exclusions from income for individuals. Chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by removing specific exclusions, deductions, and credits related to individual income tax liability. SEC. 5. Repeal of estate and gift taxes. Subtitle B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding estate, gift, and generation-skipping taxes is repealed. SEC. 6. Effective dates. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATES. The amendments made by this Act apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment date. Repeal of Estate and Gift Taxes applies to estates of decedents dying after the enactment date. The Secretary of the Treasury must submit technical changes to the Internal Revenue Code within 90 days of enactment.
